column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=Aerosols are known to affect human health , air quality , and climate and are ubiquitous in the atmosphere .
#Text=They can also act as condensation nuclei to form cloud droplets , and evaporation of liquid water from the cloud droplets allows for cycling between cloud droplets and aqueous aerosols .
#Text=Cycling between these two aqueous regimes can occur on timescales of seconds to minutes , significantly shorter than the typical lifetime of aerosols , which is roughly one week .

#Text=The uptake of water by aerosols or the evaporation of cloud droplets has the potential to impact atmospheric chemistry by altering the partitioning of semivolatile species , or perturbing equilibrium reactions in the aqueous phase .

#Text=Although the composition of aqueous aerosols can vary considerably , liquid water and aqueous organic material are a significant portion of atmospheric aerosol mass , and much of the aqueous-phase organic material that comprises aerosols is known to be secondary .
#Text=The cycling between aqueous aerosols and cloudwater provides two different aqueous environments in which aqueous secondary organic aerosol material ( aqSOA ) can form .
#Text=Since both environments are aqueous , the same chemical processes occur in both environments .

#Text=However , different processes are dominant due to the difference in water content , and therefore dilution of nonvolatile components , with aqueous aerosols having less water content per volume of air than cloudwater where clouds are present .
#Text=For example , relatively lower water content and generally lower pH are typical of aqueous aerosols , and high concentrations of organic material can limit the availability of oxidants .
#Text=This results in dark ( nonphotochemical ) reactions , such as acid-catalyzed accretion reactions and organosulfate formation , being more dominant in aerosol water than in cloudwater .

#Text=Typical cloudwater pH can range between three and six , as measured at the Whiteface Mountain Field Station summit observatory in Wilmington , NY , USA , whereas aerosol particles tend to be considerably more acidic .
#Text=Isoprene is the most abundant nonmethane hydrocarbon gas in the atmosphere and a major source of aqSOA .
#Text=One of the most significant pathways of aqSOA formation from isoprene is through the gas-phase photooxidation of isoprene to form isoprene epoxydiols ( IEPOX ) .

#Text=IEPOX secondary organic aerosols ( SOA ) , which in part consists of tetrols and organosulfates , is formed via the acid-catalyzed ring opening of the epoxide followed by nucleophilic addition of water or anions ( e.g. , HSO4− ) .
#Text=In laboratory studies , IEPOX SOA has been found to form most efficiently at low pH as a result of the acid-catalyzed ring-opening step .
#Text=The low pH and high nucleophile concentrations in aqueous aerosol provide a favorable environment for IEPOX SOA formation .

#Text=However , a number of scenarios which are believed to be common for aqueous aerosols , such as organic coatings , phase separation , or low-viscosity aerosols , are known to result in mass transfer limitations which inhibit the uptake of IEPOX into aqueous aerosols , limiting subsequent IEPOX SOA formation .
#Text=Despite this , IEPOX SOA is observed ubiquitously in the environment .
#Text=Therefore , it is possible that cloudwater may be a greater source of IEPOX SOA than previously believed .

#Text=Although the lower acidity and sulfate concentrations of cloudwater would make the rate of IEPOX SOA formation in cloudwater lower than in aqueous aerosol , other factors , such as high liquid water content and lack of organic coating or viscosity-based mass transfer limitations , may promote SOA formation .

#Text=Currently , some regional and global models cannot accurately predict atmospheric aqueous organic material due to uncertainties in SOA production despite the availability of detailed chemical models representative of atmospheric processes .
#Text=Such discrepancies between models and observed measurements may be attributed , in part , to the lack of consideration of the cycling between cloudwater and aqueous aerosol in the models .

#Text=Although several models have shown that SOA formation does occur in cloudwater , the extent to which SOA is produced as compared to formation in aqueous aerosol is unclear since very few models represent both processes .

#Text=In this work , we aim to compare IEPOX SOA production in both cloudwater and aqueous aerosols while considering the cycling that can occur between the two phases upon evaporation or condensation of water .
#Text=We used a recently updated version of GAMMA ( Gas-Aerosol Model for Mechanism Analysis ) , a photochemical box model developed by the McNeill group , to quantify IEPOX SOA formation .
#Text=We previously used GAMMA and a related model , simpleGAMMA , to predict IEPOX SOA in aqueous aerosols , and the results were in good agreement with ambient measurements .

#Text=The recent update to GAMMA includes uptake of IEPOX and subsequent formation of SOA in cloudwater , allowing for the direct comparison of the efficiency of IEPOX SOA formation in both aqueous environments , and captures the coupled effect of the two modes of processing in a single simulation .
